'''Baby Boy Warren''' (August 13, 1919 – July 1, 1977) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[singer]] and [[guitar]]ist, who was a leading figure on the [[Detroit blues]] scene in the 1950s.

==Early life==
He was born '''Robert Henry Warren''' in [[Lake Providence, Louisiana|Lake Providence]], [[Louisiana]] in 1919, but moved with his parents to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] at the age of three months.<ref name="Harris">Harris, S (1981): ''Blues Who's Who''. New York, Da Capo Press, pp. 534-535</ref> He was interested in music from an early age, and was working occasionally as a musician from around 1931, when he dropped out of school,<ref name="Harris"/> having learned to play guitar from two of his older brothers.<ref name="Russell">Russell, T. and Smith, C. (2006): ''The Penguin guide to Blues Recordings'', London: Penguin Books, p. 681</ref> During the 1930s he worked in W. C. Handy Park, Memphis, with [[Howling Wolf]], [[Robert Jr. Lockwood]], [[Little Buddy Doyle]] and others, and he appeared on the [[Helena, Arkansas|Helena]], [[Arkansas]] based [[King Biscuit Time]] radio show with [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]] around 1941.<ref name="Harris"/> In 1942 he moved to Detroit, where he worked for [[General Motors]] while also performing as a musician.<ref name="Allmusic-bio">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p136072|pure_url=yes}}|title=Baby Boy Warren: Biography |publisher= [[Allmusic]] | accessdate=2009-08-16}}</ref>

==Recordings==
Warren's first recording sessions were in 1949 and 1950 in Detroit, with the five resulting singles being released on a number of labels.<ref name="Leadbitter">Leadbitter, M. Fancourt, L. Pelletier, P. (1994): ''Blues Records 1943-1970, Vol 2, L-Z''. London. Record Information Services p. 674-5</ref> Tracks recorded at a 1954 session accompanied by Sonny Boy Williamson were released on Joe Von Battle's JVB label, and on [[Excello Records]].<ref name="Allmusic-bio"/> Further sessions the same year resulted in a single on the [[Blue Lake Records|Blue Lake]] label featuring [[Boogie Woogie Red]] on piano and [[Calvin Frazier]] on guitar, and a reworking of the [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] song "[[Stop Breakin' Down]]" for the Drummond Label.<ref name="Leadbitter"/>

==Later career and death==
Warren was mostly inactive in music during the 1960s, but revived his career to play the Detroit Blues Festival in 1971 and the [[Ann Arbor Blues Festival]] in 1973, and to tour Europe with Boogie Woogie Red in 1972.<ref name="Harris"/> From 1974 to 1976 he was also a featured performer, along with [[Willie D. Warren]], with the Progressive Blues Band, a popular blues band that played in many of Detroit's best blues venues.<ref name="AMG 2">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=willie-d-warren-p391268/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Willie D. Warren |author=Reif, Fred |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 14, 2010}}</ref>

He suffered a fatal [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at his home on July 1, 1977, and was buried at Detroit Memorial Park Cemetery, [[Macomb County, Michigan|Macomb County]], [[Michigan]].<ref name="Harris"/>

==Personal information==
Warren was given the nickname "Baby Boy" by his older brothers as a child.  One of 12 children himself, he married twice, in 1935 and the early 1960s, and had seven children. On the [[Staff Records|Staff]], [[Federal Records|Federal]] and [[Swing Time Records|Swing Time]] labels he was marketed as Johnny Williams.<ref name="Harris"/>

==Influences==
His chief influences were Little Buddy Doyle and Willie "61" Blackwell, especially in his approach to [[lyrics]],<ref name="Russell"/> and he stated that another musician he particularly admired was [[Memphis Minnie]], who he knew in Memphis in the 1930s.<ref>Garon, P. and Garon, B. (1992): ''Woman With Guitar: Memphis Minnie's Blues''. New York, Da Capo Press, pp. 4 & 197</ref>  ''The Penguin Guide to Blues Recordings'' described him as having brought "a hip, literate humour to the blues lyric".
